Opinion: Minister Dubé, I challenge you to come see what doctors do

Bill 2 ignores what every patient and health professional in Quebec knows: You cannot meet performance targets without the means to perform.

Author of the article:
By Nader Sadeghi  •  Special to the Montreal Gazette
Published Oct 31, 2025
Last updated 5 hours ago
5 minute read
Article content

Come spend a week with me — from early morning to midnight. That’s my challenge to Health Minister Christian Dubé.

Article content

Come walk the hospital corridors, the recovery rooms, and the operating theatres where we do our best to care for patients despite a system that has been on life support for years. Watch how we spend our days trying to find beds, staff and operating-room time — and our nights catching up on the cases we could not do by day. See what it truly takes to keep Quebec’s health-care system functioning.

Article content
We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Opinion: Minister Dubé, I challenge you to come see what doctors do Back to video

Article content
Advertisement 1
Story continues below
This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.
Article content

Two years ago, I wrote that our system was breathing through a ventilator. Today, it still is — except that now, instead of helping the patient breathe, the government has decided to blame the physicians for its condition.

Article content

In the early hours of Oct. 25, the National Assembly adopted Bill 2, a special law that unilaterally changes how every physician in Quebec will be paid. A portion of our compensation will now depend on government-defined performance targets: the number of patients we see, the delays before surgery, the collective “access indicators” we meet.

Article content

On paper, this sounds like accountability. In reality, it is collective scapegoating. The law ignores the most basic fact known to every patient and every doctor in this province: You cannot meet performance targets without the means to perform.

Article content

Bill 2 (derived from Bill 106, for those keeping score) does not open a single closed operating room, hire an extra nurse, or add an ICU bed. It simply transfers responsibility for systemic failure onto those who have been holding the system together.

Article content
Advertisement 2
Story continues below
This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.
Article content

It even bans physicians from “concerted actions” — any co-ordinated attempt to protest — under threat of fines reaching half a million dollars per day. This is not reform. It is coercion disguised as efficiency.

Article content
Read More
  1. Letter of the day: My husband is neither lazy nor greedy. No doctor is
  2. Opinion: Quebec's imposed health reform echoes errors from 1990s
  3. Advertisement 1
    Story continues below
    This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.
Article content

The scale of the problem can be seen in one comparison. In 1980, the metropolitan population of Montreal was about 2.7 million. At that time, the Royal Victoria Hospital — a major teaching and tertiary-care centre — ran 12 operating rooms, able to manage emergencies without cancelling scheduled cases.

Article content

In 2025, the Montreal region counts roughly 4.36 million residents. Yet the Royal Victoria, now part of the McGill University Health Centre, while budgeted to run 11 ORs, runs only seven on a typical day due to lack of specialized staff. Surgical capacity has nearly halved while the population has almost doubled.

Article content

For a hospital that serves as a provincial referral centre for cancer, transplant, cardiac and vascular surgery, among others, this is catastrophic.

Advertisement 1
This advertisement has not loaded yet.

    Local News
Advertisement 2
Advertisement
This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.
Article content

Every week, cases are cancelled not for lack of skill or will, but for lack of staff or equipment. We decide who waits, not because we want to, but because we must, because we have to prioritize the most urgent cases. We are working under constant crisis conditions.

Article content

Recently, I admitted a patient with a rapidly advancing cancer. The tumour is growing, threatening vital structures. Under normal conditions, he should be operated on within days. But I have access to the OR only three days per month, and if I get lucky, four days. How do I function as a cancer surgeon with so little access?

Article content

To prevent further progression, I admitted my patient under an “emergency” designation, hoping that a slot might open. As I write this, he has waited 48 hours, fasting each morning, uncertain whether his turn will come. Every few hours, a new emergency — more urgent and immediately threatening limb or life — rightfully takes precedence.

Article content

If I am lucky, I may operate late at night or over the following few days if other more urgent emergencies do not keep coming through. If not, he keeps waiting, anxious and deteriorating.

Article content
Advertisement 3
Story continues below
This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.
Article content

The emotional toll is crushing. For every patient I help, another must wait. The suffering multiplies, and I am forced to make impossible decisions while keeping composed to provide the best care I can to my patients. I can only imagine the anxiety of my patients and their families experiencing this situation.

Article content

Bill 2 assumes that if doctors are pressured by sanctions and fines, access will magically improve. But what happens when there are not enough nurses, respiratory therapists and anesthesiologists to staff the operating and recovery rooms? When hospital and ICU beds are closed? When entire ORs sit idle for lack of personnel?

Article content

As the Fédération des médecins spécialistes du Québec (FMSQ) rightly warned, these laws impose targets without providing tools. The Fédération des médecins omnipraticiens du Québec (FMOQ) added that linking goals to remuneration will demotivate physicians and reduce accessibility.

Article content

They are correct. Every surgeon in this province could double his or her workload tomorrow — if the infrastructure allowed it. But it doesn’t. And the government knows it. The effect of this new law will be to demoralize a workforce already exhausted and to push more doctors toward early retirement or out of the province entirely. That means fewer caregivers for Quebecers, not more.

Article content
Advertisement 4
Story continues below
This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.
Article content

Behind every delayed case is a person — often frightened, often deteriorating. Cancer progresses while waiting for a surgery date. Joint disease becomes disability. A treatable condition becomes an emergency. Each cancellation is a quiet act of heartbreak.

Article content

We trained for years to heal, to intervene before it is too late. Yet we find ourselves explaining to patients that their surgery cannot proceed because the OR is not available. The burden of that conversation is ours to bear, but the cause is not ours to fix.

Article content

If accountability is truly what the government seeks, let us measure what matters: How many ORs stand closed each day in Quebec hospitals? How many beds are blocked for lack of staff? How many clinicians, nurses and technicians have left the public system?

Article content

Those are the indicators that define whether Quebecers receive the care they deserve. Accountability should start at the top — with those who control the resources, not with those struggling to deliver care in their absence.

Advertisement 2
This advertisement has not loaded yet.
Advertisement 3
Story continues below
This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.
Article content

To Dubé, I say: Before legislating our “performance,” come see how we actually work. Come stand beside us and watch how, because of a lack of resources, we must personally call, text and email our colleagues to move each patient through the system — to secure an imaging, consultations, beds or an operating room. Come watch as nurses stretch their shifts.

Article content

Then ask yourself whether the problem lies with those doing the work — or with the system that has abandoned them.

Article content

We are not adversaries. Physicians, nurses and allied professionals are your greatest allies in rebuilding a humane, efficient and modern public health system. But a partnership cannot be built on accusation. It begins with recognition — of what we do, what we lack and what must change.

Article content

Until that happens, the system will continue to suffocate, and no law will make it breathe again.

Article content

Nader Sadeghi is a professor and chair in the department of otolaryngology – head and neck surgery at McGill University, director of McGill’s head and neck cancer program, chief of otolaryngology – head and neck surgery at the MUHC, and investigator with the cancer research program at the Research Institute of the MUHC.

Article content
